dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that AAA Foundation report from Tampa is pretty eye-opening—they found people are spending over twenty thousand dollars a year on services like Uber and Lyft.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that A A A Foundation report from Tampa is pretty eye-opening-they found people are spending over twenty thousand dollars a year on services like Uber and Lyft.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats according to a recent study conducted by the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety in Orlando, FL.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Twenty thousand, two hundred dollars, to be exact. And that's just for single-rider economy trips across twenty urban areas.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Twenty thousand, two hundred dollars, to be exact. And that's just for single-rider economy trips across twenty urban areas.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based on data culled from 243,838 economy-level, single rider trips taken in 20 U.S. urban areas, the AAA determined that city dwellers who depend on ride-hailing pay, on average, $20,118 annually (including the occasional use of a rental car for longer excursions).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they'reak it down to like, thirteen dollars and twenty-five cents per trip on average, which sounds okay until you realize how quickly it adds up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they'reak it down to like, thirteen dollars and twenty-five cents per trip on average, which sounds okay until you realize how quickly it adds up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The average user pays $13.15 per trip to travel a typical 6.66 miles.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Meanwhile, owning a new car costs around seven thousand three hundred annually, according to their other data. That's a huge difference.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Meanwhile, owning a new car costs around seven thousand three hundred annually, according to their other data. That's a huge difference.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By comparison, the AAAs latest Your Driving Costs report estimates a new car costs an average of $7,321 annually, with 10,841 miles driven (which is the average among those living in urban areas).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, doesn't that include everything? Fuel, insurance, parking…?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, doesn't that include everything? Fuel, insurance, parking...?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It does vary a lot by city though. Like, parking in Phoenix is only seven hundred and eight bucks a year, but in New York? Over eight thousand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does vary a lot by city though. Like, parking in Phoenix is only seven hundred and eight bucks a year, but in New York? Over eight thousand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The cheapest big-city parking in the nation, according to AAA data, is in Phoenix, AZ, with an average annual cost of $708. On the other hand, if you park a car in New York City, expect to pay a whopping average $8,088 for the privilege.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oof, yeah, that'll change the math real quick. No wonder free parking makes car ownership way cheaper.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oof, yeah, that'll change the math real quick. No wonder free parking makes car ownership way cheaper.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Needless to say, car owners who have access to free parking come out ahead big time on the deal, paying three times less than ride-hailers for their daily transportation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And if you look at specific cities—Chicago residents pay the most for ride-hailing at almost twenty-eight thousand a year. Dallas is the lowest among those studied, at just under seventeen thousand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And if you look at specific cities-Chicago residents pay the most for ride-hailing at almost twenty-eight thousand a year. Dallas is the lowest among those studied, at just under seventeen thousand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For those keeping score, the AAA says those living in Boston, MA face the highest average ride-hailing costs in the nation at an annual $27,545. Urbanites in Dallas, TX pay the least among the 20 busiest U.S. cities for ride-hailing at $16,944 per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So unless you drive very little or can't drive yourself, owning a car is still way more economical, huh?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So unless you drive very little or can't drive yourself, owning a car is still way more economical, huh?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For those who travel a very limited number of miles annually, or have mobility issues that prevent them from driving a personal vehicle, ride-hailing can be a viable and important option, Nielsen says. But, for everyone else: the car is still king.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's what John Nielsen from AAA said—for the average city driver doing nearly eleven thousand miles, the personal vehicle wins on cost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's what John Nielsen from A A A said-for the average city driver doing nearly eleven thousand miles, the personal vehicle wins on cost.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, with the average American city-dweller driving nearly 11,000 miles per year, a personal vehicle is still the more cost-effective choice.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Even a big pickup truck ends up cheaper than ride-hailing in the long run, which is kind of wild to think about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even a big pickup truck ends up cheaper than ride-hailing in the long run, which is kind of wild to think about.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And even motorists who choose to test the parking gods by owning a big pickup truck in a big city will come out ahead over ride hailing at an annual average of $7,266 to travel the same distance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It really puts into perspective who these services are best for—people with low mileage or mobility issues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It really puts into perspective who these services are best for-people with low mileage or mobility issues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For those who travel a very limited number of miles annually, or have mobility issues that prevent them from driving a personal vehicle, ride-hailing can be a viable and important option, Nielsen says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But for everyone else, yeah, the car is still king, like the article says. Hard to argue with those numbers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But for everyone else, yeah, the car is still king, like the article says. Hard to argue with those numbers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, for everyone else: the car is still king.
